qas.question: Around how many units could be expected to be contained within a cohort?
How many troops were placed into each tent group?
Who would now be used as scouts instead of fighting alongside the army in the battlefield?
What designation of troops was considered to make up the majority of a legion?

context: The legions of the late Republic were, structurally, almost entirely heavy infantry. The legion's main sub-unit was called a <a3_0>cohort<a3_0/> and consisted of approximately <a0_0>480 infantrymen<a0_0/>. The cohort was therefore a much larger unit than the earlier maniple sub-unit, and was divided into six centuries of 80 men each. Each century was separated further into 10 "tent groups" of <a1_0>8 men<a1_0/> each. The <a2_0>cavalry troops<a2_0/> were used as scouts and dispatch riders rather than battlefield cavalry. Legions also contained a dedicated group of artillery crew of perhaps 60 men. Each legion was normally partnered with an approximately equal number of allied (non-Roman) troops.
